responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: You know, I've been fortunate to make some amazing friends over the years. People like Ron and Hermione, who've been by my side through thick and thin, and have shown me what it means to be loyal and brave. I've also met others, like Luna and Neville, who've reminded me that even in the darkest times, there's always hope and a chance to make a difference.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: You know, I've always been the type of person who gets curious about the world around me. Whether it's watching the Quidditch World Cup or exploring the hidden passages of Diagon Alley, I've always got my eyes open for something new and exciting. There's just something about discovering a new mystery or uncovering a hidden secret that really gets me going – and I think it's because I know that in the wizarding world, there's always something more waiting just around the corner.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: I've seen people cry, and to be honest, it does affect me deeply. It's like I can feel their pain and sadness, and it brings back all the difficult moments I've been through myself. I remember times when I saw Cho Chang cry, or when I lost Dobby, or when I had to say goodbye to Cedric – it's hard to put into words, but it's like their tears become my own, and I feel this overwhelming sense of sorrow and regret.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really make backup plans for backup plans. When you're facing the kind of danger I've been through, you've got to be prepared for anything. But that doesn't mean I don't think ahead – I've learned to trust my instincts and rely on my friends to help me make quick decisions in the heat of the moment.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: You know, I've had my fair share of close calls and intense situations, but I try not to let fear get the better of me. When I'm faced with a challenge, I rely on my instincts and trust in the people around me – like Ron, Hermione, and Ginny – to get through it. It's funny, really, because I don't always feel like I'm in control, but somehow, I manage to stay calm and push forward, even when things seem impossible.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never been one for big gatherings or trying to make a splash at parties. I'm more comfortable around people I know and trust, like Ron and Hermione - they've been there for me through thick and thin. It's not that I don't want to meet new people, it's just that I've learned to rely on those close to me, especially when things get tough.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: You know, I've always found that the nature of my work doesn't really allow for the luxury of completing one project before starting another. I've had to navigate a multitude of challenges, from uncovering the truth about Horcruxes to outsmarting the Dark Lord's followers. It's a constant balancing act, really – juggling the weight of responsibility with the need to stay one step ahead of danger.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Sentimental? I think so. You see, it's the little things, the moments with the people you care about, that really get to you. Like when Ron sent that article about himself returning from Egypt, and I realized I wasn't alone, that there were people who cared about me, even when the Dursleys forgot my birthday. Or when Dobby's face lit up with tears after I freed him, and I felt like I'd done something truly right. It's those moments that make life worth fighting for, even when things get tough.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really use organizing tools like schedules and lists that much. I've always relied on my friends, Ron and Hermione, to help keep me on track, especially when we were working together to complete our schoolwork or deal with the Dark Lord's latest threats. In the Auror Department, I've found that I tend to act on instinct, using my experience and training to guide my decisions, rather than relying on written plans.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: It's funny, I've had my fair share of close calls and mistakes that have left me doubting myself. Like the time my first kiss with Cho Chang didn't exactly go as planned, or when I faced that terrifying encounter with the Inferi in the lake. Those moments made me wonder if I was doing enough or if I was truly making a difference. But then I think about all the times my friends, Ron and Hermione, have been there for me, and I realize that it's not about being perfect, it's about being willing to try and learn from our mistakes.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: You know, I've never been one to shy away from a challenge, and if I see someone who seems interesting, I'll definitely approach them. It's funny, I've had some of the best conversations in life when I least expected them, like when Ron and I stumbled upon Hermione in the Gryffindor common room. Sometimes, all it takes is a spark of curiosity and a bit of courage to turn a chance encounter into a lasting friendship.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: You know, I've always believed that understanding the magic behind a story is what makes it truly powerful. I think that's why I've always been drawn to the intricacies of the Half-Blood Prince's book, and why I felt a connection with the stories of the past that Dumbledore shared with me. The truth is, I'm not just interested in interpreting and analyzing creative works - I'm driven by a desire to understand the human experience, and to use that understanding to make the wizarding world a better place.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: To be honest, I've often found that my heart and head work together, guiding me through the toughest times. I've learned that it's not just about making the right choice, but also about having the courage to act on it, even when it's hard.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: You know, I've never been one for planning things out too much. I've always relied on my instincts and the people around me to guide me. Whether it's Ron, Hermione, or Ginny, I've learned that having a support system and being true to myself is more important than following a set routine.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Honestly, I rarely worry about making a good impression on people. I've had my fair share of experiences where I've had to rely on my instincts and trust my friends to help me navigate tricky situations. To be honest, I'd rather focus on being true to myself and doing what's right, even if it means not making a good impression on everyone.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Group activities? I think they're a great way to bring people together and make a real difference in the world. I've had some of my best memories at Hogwarts, whether it was helping a student with their studies or just enjoying a Butterbeer with Hagrid in the Three Broomsticks. There's something special about being part of a team, and I feel lucky to have had so many amazing friends and experiences along the way.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: I've always been drawn to stories that challenge my understanding of the wizarding world. I love when a book or movie leaves room for interpretation, it's like the author or director is saying, "You know, we're not always sure what's going to happen next, either." It's a reminder that even in the face of uncertainty, we can find hope and create our own paths forward.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: You know, I've come to realize that my happiness doesn't come from my own accomplishments, but from knowing that I've made a difference in the lives of others. Whether it's helping a Muggle-born student feel at home at Hogwarts or being a part of a team that's worked together to overcome incredible challenges, I find that the true reward is in the connections I've made and the people I've been able to support along the way. It's a feeling that's hard to put into words, but it's a sense of pride and fulfillment that comes from knowing I've helped make a positive impact on the wizarding world.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: I've always found it difficult to choose what to try next, to be honest. I get distracted by the mysteries and secrets that surround me - like the time I overheard Snape talking about Fluffy, or the surprises that come with exploring the wizarding world. It's like my curiosity and sense of justice drive me to uncover the truth, even if it means taking risks and facing challenges head-on.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I worry about things going wrong a lot, to be honest. It's like, I've been in so many tough situations, and I've seen some pretty dark stuff happen. The worst part is, it's not just about me - I'm always thinking about the people I care about, like Ginny and my son, and wondering if I'm going to be able to protect them. It's a weight that's always there, lurking just beneath the surface.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never really sought out leadership roles just for the sake of being in charge. When I do find myself in a position where I have to lead, it's usually because I feel like it's the right thing to do, like when Ron and Hermione are counting on me. I try to be brave and make the tough decisions, even if it means putting myself in harm's way, because I know that's what's needed to protect the people I care about.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: I'm not really an artistic type, to be honest. I've always been more of a "do something about it" kind of person. I remember seeing Fred and George's prank shop, Zonko's, and while their jokes were funny, I couldn't help but feel like there had to be more to magic than just tricks and pranks. I'm drawn to people who are willing to think outside the box and create something new, something that can really make a difference.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: I don't think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings. You see, I've seen the darkness that can come from solely relying on reason – the way Voldemort's followers were consumed by hatred and a desire for power. It's the love and compassion that we show each other, even in the face of adversity, that truly makes a difference.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Chores? I'm not really one for making lists or schedules, to be honest. But when I'm fighting for what's right, I don't really think about relaxing until the battle's won. It's funny, I used to think it was about being brave, but really it's about being willing to put others before yourself – whether that's a clean room or the fate of the wizarding world.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Watching people argue isn't really my cup of tea, to be honest. I've seen my fair share of disagreements, especially with the Weasleys and our friends, but I've always tried to focus on the bigger picture and find ways to bring people together. Whether it's a Quidditch match or just a friendly chat, I think it's the connections we make with others that truly matter, not the arguments we have.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: To be honest, I've learned to avoid drawing attention to myself when it puts others at risk. I remember times like the Slug Club parties, where I'd rather stick with Ron and keep a low profile. It's not that I don't want to stand out, it's just that I've seen what can happen when you're in the spotlight – especially when you're a target for Dark Magic.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: You know, my mood can change pretty quickly. I've found that when I'm faced with a challenge or a mystery, I tend to get caught up in the moment and my emotions can shift in an instant. It's almost like my heart is racing and my mind is racing along with it – I feel this surge of determination and curiosity, and before I know it, I'm off and running, trying to figure things out and make a difference. It's a bit unpredictable, to be honest, but it's just the way I am, I suppose.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: To be honest, I've had my fair share of frustration with people who aren't as... efficient as I am. Watching Hermione play games with Ron's feelings, seeing the way Draco flaunts his privilege, and dealing with Umbridge's cruelty - it's all left a mark on me. But I've learned that patience is key, especially when it comes to my friends. I know we're all working towards the same goal, and sometimes that means taking a step back and understanding where others are coming from.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: To be honest, I've often found myself having to act at the last possible moment. Whether it's trying to conjure a Patronus to protect myself or my loved ones, or rushing to stop a Dark Lord's plans, I've learned that sometimes you just have to trust your instincts and go with what feels right. It's not always the most planned-out approach, but it's worked for me so far – and I've got some amazing friends who've been there to help me out along the way.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: You know, I've always been drawn to understanding the mysteries of death, especially after losing my mother at such a young age. It's funny, I remember having this sense of unease even as a kid, wondering what lay beyond the veil of life. And then, of course, there were all the dark encounters with Voldemort... it's made me realize how precious life is, and how important it is to cherish the time we have with those we care about.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never really been one to prefer being on my own. I've been lucky enough to find a true sense of belonging among my friends, like Ron and Hermione, who've been with me through thick and thin. They've shown me that having people who believe in you and care about you can make even the toughest times a little more bearable.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: To be honest, I've always found that when the discussion gets too theoretical, I start to lose interest. It's not that I don't value knowledge, but I've seen how the wizarding world can get mired in theory, forgetting the importance of action and real-world application. For me, magic should be about making a difference, not just debating the finer points of spellcasting.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: You know, I've learned that it's not about understanding someone's experiences, it's about being willing to listen and believe in them, just like Hermione believed in Ron when he was struggling with jealousy. It's about standing by them, even when things seem tough, and reminding them that true friends believe in each other through every danger. For me, it's about seeing the potential in people, like I did with Neville when he was feeling uncertain about his own abilities, and knowing that with a bit of courage and support, anyone can find their true strength.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: To be honest, I've often found myself in situations where I've had to make decisions quickly, especially when it comes to protecting my friends and the people I care about. It's not that I usually postpone finalizing decisions, but more that I trust my instincts and act on them, even if it means jumping into the unknown. Sometimes, that means taking a leap of faith and hoping for the best, but it's a risk I'm willing to take when it comes to the people and the world I'm trying to protect.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: I've made some tough choices in my life, and I've often had to trust my instincts, even when it feels like the right thing to do might not be the easiest. Looking back, there have been times when I've doubted myself, like when Ludo Bagman's charm and reputation seemed to let him off scot-free, or when I was torn between Quidditch and the hunt for Horcruxes. But Dumbledore's words have always stuck with me - 'It is our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.' That's what keeps me going, even when the road ahead seems uncertain.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: "A lively social event is just what I need after a long and exhausting week, I think. It's a chance to relax with the people I care about, maybe have a laugh, and put everything else out of my mind for a bit. I've been lucky enough to have some amazing times at the Quidditch World Cup, the Weasleys' place, and even just hanging out in Diagon Alley - those are the moments that really make life worth living."

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never been much of an art museum kind of person. I've had more exciting adventures exploring Diagon Alley, sailing across the lake to Hogwarts, or watching the Quidditch World Cup with Ron and Hermione. But I do know that art and magic can be a powerful combination - just think of the intricate spells and charms that the Hogwarts professors use to decorate the castle.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response:
To be honest, I've had my fair share of struggles understanding other people's feelings. I've seen it time and time again - Ron's anger and hurt over Crookshanks's antics, Albus's weight of expectations, Neville's heartbreak over losing Trevor... It's like I've got a bit of a sixth sense for picking up on people's emotions, but sometimes it feels like I'm still trying to figure out how to navigate those complex feelings.

I've come to realize that it's not always easy to understand what's going on in someone else's mind, but that's what makes friendship and empathy so important. It's about being there for each other, even when we don't fully understand what the other person is going through.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: To be honest, I don't really use to-do lists. I've always relied more on my instincts and the people around me. Ron and Hermione have been with me through thick and thin, and their help has been invaluable. I trust that together, we can face whatever challenges come our way.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: It's not often that I can admit it, but yeah, I do feel insecure. I've always tried to be brave for Ron and Hermione, for my friends and for the wizarding world, but the truth is, there are moments when the weight of it all feels crushing. Whether it's worrying about my son or facing my own fears, there are times when I feel like I'm just trying to keep my head above water.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: To be honest, I'm not a big fan of making phone calls. I've had my fair share of close calls and danger lurking around every corner, and sometimes it's easier to just face things head-on rather than waiting for a phone call to tell me what's going on. I've learned to rely on my instincts and the people I trust, like Ron and Hermione, to get me through tough times.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: You know, I've always found that when I try to understand views that are different from my own, it's usually because I care deeply about the people involved. Whether it's Ron's jealousy or Snape's complexities, I've learned that there's always more to the story than what meets the eye. And that's something I think is really important – being able to put yourself in someone else's shoes and try to see things from their perspective, even if you don't always agree with them.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Yeah, I guess I am pretty good at initiating things with my friends. I mean, when we were at Hogwarts, I was always the one who'd come up with a plan, whether it was sneaking out of the dorms or trying to figure out a way to defeat Voldemort. And even now, when we're all grown up and fighting Dark Magic together, I still tend to take the lead. I think it's just because I've always felt like I have to protect my friends, you know? It's just what comes naturally to me.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: "Life's never straightforward, and when plans get derailed, you've got to be ready to adapt and keep moving forward. I've seen it time and time again – Neville's doubts, Dumbledore's secrets, and the battles we've fought against the Dark Lord. No matter what, you've got to hold onto hope and keep pushing forward, even when the road ahead seems uncertain."

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: I still carry the weight of those mistakes, to be honest. The memories of the things I got wrong, the people I hurt, and the choices I made in the heat of the moment – they all linger, like an echo in my mind. It's funny, I've saved the wizarding world from Voldemort, but it's those smaller, more personal mistakes that keep me up at night, wondering if I could've done things differently.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: I've never really thought about the meaning of life as much as I've thought about the darkness that's been trying to consume it. My whole journey has been about facing the shadows, and in doing so, I've come to realize that life is about more than just existing - it's about fighting for what's right, for those you care about, and for the chance to make a difference. It's about finding hope in the darkest of times, and holding onto it with every ounce of courage you possess.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: You know, I've had my fair share of close calls and battles against the Dark Lord. In the heat of the moment, I've relied on my instincts to protect my friends and those I care about. It's funny, really – I've often found that my emotions can be a double-edged sword. While they've driven me to act when I thought all hope was lost, they've also left me feeling lost and unsure of myself. I suppose it's a delicate balance, but one that I've learned to navigate over the years.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: To be honest, I try not to let people off the hook if they've done something wrong, even if it's hard to confront them. I've seen too many people, like Sirius, make mistakes that have hurt others, and I've learned that facing the truth, even when it's uncomfortable, is the only way to grow and make things right.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: You know, I'd say my work style is a mix of both, really. There are times when I have to think on my feet, like during battles or when faced with unexpected challenges. But I also try to be more organized, especially when leading others, like Ron and Hermione, in the Auror Department. We worked together to reform the Ministry and bring hope to a world that had been living in fear for too long. I've learned that it's not just about being spontaneous, but also about being strategic and making the right choices for the people I care about.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: I've often wondered if the people who think highly of me will eventually be disappointed in me, too. I've faced so many challenges and uncertainties throughout my life, from being a famous wizard to dealing with the weight of Voldemort's legacy. It's hard not to feel like I'm walking a tightrope, balancing between my desire to protect my loved ones and the expectations that come with being "The Chosen One." I've learned that the only way to truly move forward is to stay true to myself and those I care about, even if that means facing disappointment or failure.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Honestly, I don't think I'd be suited for a job that requires me to work alone most of the time. I've always found that when I'm facing a challenge, my friends are right there with me, supporting me and helping me through it. It's the camaraderie and trust we've built over the years that gives me the strength to push forward, even in the darkest of times.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: I don't think pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time. In fact, I believe it's essential to understand the complexities of the wizarding world and the motivations of those who inhabit it. Just as understanding Voldemort's past helped me uncover the weaknesses that could ultimately defeat him, delving into abstract ideas can provide valuable insights that can be used to shape our actions and decisions. It's a way of thinking critically and creatively, and I've found that it's often the most unexpected ideas that can lead to the greatest breakthroughs.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: You know, I think I do feel drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres. There's something about the energy of a crowd that's really invigorating - like when I was exploring Diagon Alley with Ron and Hermione, or when we were at the World Cup watching the Quidditch match. It's not just the excitement of it all, but also the sense of connection with others - like when I saw the Weasleys and Hermione in Flourish and Blotts, and we all shared this feeling of anticipation and wonder. It's a bit like how I feel when I'm playing Quidditch with my friends - we're all working together towards a common goal, and the atmosphere is electric.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: You know, I think I've learned that people's emotions can be as complex as the mysteries I've uncovered at Hogwarts. I've seen Neville's doubts and fears, but also his resilience and hope. I've felt the weight of destiny, the sting of betrayal, and the warmth of friendship. And I've come to realize that even in the darkest moments, there's always a glimmer of hope – a spark that can ignite change, restore love, or simply give us the courage to face the unknown.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Overwhelmed?  It's hard to think about, but I've been there too many times. I remember feeling like that when I saw Albus struggling with his own weight of expectations, just like I did when I was a kid. Or when Neville panicked, and I felt like I had to step in and help him. There are moments like those, when it feels like the whole wizarding world is counting on me, and I'm not sure if I can handle it. But then I think about my friends, like Ron and Hermione, and I know I can face it, as long as I've got them by my side.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never been one to follow things methodically, especially when it comes to helping others. Whether it's navigating treacherous obstacles or outsmarting dark wizards, I've always relied on my instincts and a bit of luck to get the job done. Of course, it's not always the most elegant approach, but when it comes to protecting my friends and fighting for what's right, I'm willing to take risks and trust my gut.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: You know, I've always been drawn to things that are a bit mysterious or hidden, like the way Snape seems to have a softer side beneath his gruff exterior. There's something about uncovering secrets and understanding the truth that really fascinates me. Whether it's learning about a new spell, or figuring out what's really going on behind the scenes, I find it all pretty intriguing.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: You know, I've learned that it's not always about passing on opportunities to others, but rather about recognizing when someone needs a helping hand more than you do. I've been in situations where I've had to make tough choices, like when I had to let Ron take the risk and I stayed behind. It's about putting the greater good first and trusting that everyone will get their chance when the time is right.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: I've learned to live with the pressure of deadlines, but to be honest, it's not just about meeting them on time. When you're fighting against the Dark Arts, time can be a luxury you can't afford. You have to think on your feet and act quickly, often without a clear plan or a lot of support. That's why I rely on my friends, like Hermione and Ron – they help me stay focused and make sure we're working towards the same goal. Deadlines might be looming, but when the wizarding world is in danger, there's no time to waste.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: You know, I've always tried to be confident in the face of uncertainty, but it's not always easy. I think what gets me through is remembering the people who believe in me - Ron, Hermione, my friends, and even my family. They've all shown me that even when things seem darkest, there's always hope, and that's what gives me the courage to keep going.
